So... what is _actually_ stopping Riot from making such a champion?

Currently, there are four female champions in League who would be considered "tanky."

* Leona - Superheroine physique in armor with a big shield.
* Sejuani - Formerly bikini-clad warrior from the frigid north.
* Shyvana - Half-dragon lady with carefully placed armor plates, otherwise scantily clad (Classic skin).
* Rek'sai - Bestial inhuman jungler, can be regarded as "female in lore only."

I mean, there has to be some legitimate reason why we can't have a "Mother Bear"-type champion in LoL.  Do people from marketing or animation on the champion committees veto or downvote such a design as "not marketable" or "not League enough?"  Are the "advocates for equal representation" within the art department just not strong enough to stand firm and say "No, this champ has to be done as a strong, brawny female."

It's one thing to _say_ that there's a desire for certain designs.  It's another to actually do that.

Because Rito doesn't just have a meeting one day and go "omg guys, we need big chix." No, they think of awesome stories and themes and concepts and slap em all together into one big awesome and cohesive champion.

For example, Jinx was more than just "err merr gerrd guys we need flat chested chix!" - _que development_

And Rek'Sai wasn't just "ermergerd GUYS! We.Need.MONSTER CHIX." - _que development_

> [{quoted}](name=Sleeper Cell,realm=NA,application-id=A8FQeEA8,discussion-id=7P082r30,comment-id=000500030001,timestamp=2015-10-11T18:50:40.846+0000)
>
> Because Rito doesn't just have a meeting one day and go "omg guys, we need big chix." No, they think of awesome stories and themes and concepts and slap em all together into one big awesome and cohesive champion.

It _could_ be that.  It could just as easily that someone came up with a "buff lady" idea and it was vetoed during the process for some less than savory reasons.

Take, as an example, Vi.  Vi, a champion with big gauntlets that punches things to oblivion, could have easily been a buff tank lady.  Maybe not to the level of the OP's suggestion, but certainly strong-looking enough to not need a harness to carry her gloves.

Instead, someone at Marketing/E-Commerce might have said "We can't market a concept this 'brutal' as easily as we could a more attractive female.  Please change it." Or, one of those "strong advocate for equality" concept artists might have said "I don't want to draw this champion as a buff woman, but as an alternative model with a pink mohawk and a steel corset."

Hence, an opportunity is lost because of individual decisions within a group.  More than possible, either way...

> For example, Jinx was more than just "err merr gerrd guys we need flat chested chix!" - _que development_

That's funny.  You actually point to the one example where the concept artist, TeaTime, drew something unexpected (a short, skinny champion with lots of guns) and the team went with it all the way.

To quote a Red, Riot needs more than "Buff mother bear type champ lol!" to make a champion.  They need art concept, a kit idea, lore, ect and so on.  It's entirely possible to get this type of champ made, but there's a good bit of foot work involved.  Riot already has a docket full of champs on the way, so while it's possible they may do this kind of champ in time, it could be a while before they are ready to release something like that.
IMO, the quickest way to get a champ like this in the works, the players need to jump in and put together ideas, concepts, kits, lore, all the works.  The less Riot has to work on, the faster they can work to put together a champ.

From what I've gathered over the past four years, Riot mostly works by committee.  They have game designers, artists, animators, narrative writers, marketers and other people gather to work on new champions, starting at the concept phase.  Then, after a period of time, they come back to review ideas and concepts before focusing on specific directions (art, story, animation, gameplay, etc.)

I'll use Vi as an example, again.

Vi is a young woman who punches opponents with large gauntlets.  She can be built fairly tanky and still be effective in the game.  Now, at this concept level, someone might have had Sarah Robles (American powerlifter) or Beth Phoenix (WWE Diva/wrestler) in mind for a gauntlet-wearing tanky puncher.  Instead, the concept artist chose to use "Suicide Girl in a steel corset" as the basis for the champion.  For various reasons (easier sell, fun design choice, excited to draw and animate hot chick, etc) the committee chose to move forward with the "suicide girl" model concept.

> IMO, the quickest way to get a champ like this in the works, the players need to jump in and put together ideas, concepts, kits, lore, all the works.  The less Riot has to work on, the faster they can work to put together a champ.
> {{champion:201}}

Weeeellllllll..... Braum ain't _exactly_ Angus the Puncher, is he?  Inspired by, possibly, but [Braum was actually "Cece the Hextech Engineer"](https://youtu.be/ggMX6ZOrrV4?t=3m) at first until they went in a new direction.

I mean, I really hope Riot does meet this goal for a buff lady champ some day, but I'm not going to buy the idea that they "haven't had the opportunity" during the past four plus years.
It's not about equal representation, league champs aren't democratically elected. It's about common sense: a strong person is more likely to be useful in war than a weakling.

I think it is more the frustration with only having slim or athletic female characters.
It isn't about representation or identification, but boredom.

It is very much, "oh another standard female body type with an accessory that shows their role", such as punching, defending, shooting. While there are some standouts, and some make sense, there isn't anything as clean or concise as a Dwarf style character for instance that you can tell at a glance can take a heavy hit even without any signifying gear like a shield. The obviously female tanks look tanky due to their equipment, not because they themselves are tough. Sejuani is probably the closest character, but still stops at being athletic instead of stout.

I am personally doubtful Poppy will be reworked into that role based on what Riot has been saying about the rework and instead double down on the "small girl with giant hammer" motif.

I already explained this in another comment thread to more detail, but i'll summarize here -- I just trust female artists to get the job done better.  They do a better job at drawing female champs.  I'm zero percent surprised Leona was drawn by a guy.  Boob armor, skinny as hell, big luxurious model hair instead of a helmet and splotchy, not functional armor.  She only looks like a tank cause she has a giant shield (one with a giant hole in it, on top of that), and even then barely.  Take away a shield, and youd never let her into combat, much less be a tank, she'd snap like a twig.  I'm sure she's very fappable, but thats the problem -- making champs pretty instead of cool and badass.  Girls tend to not do that, cause they want to make a cool person they can see themselves as, not make something a guy will enjoy aesthetically.
